review.title: An axiomatic approach to the roughness measure of rough sets
review.abstract: In Pawlak's rough set theory, each rough set is approximated by a pair of lower and upper approximations. To measure numerically the roughness of an approximation, Pawlak introduced a quantitative measure of roughness by using the ratio of the cardinalities of the lower and upper approximations. Although the roughness measure is effective, it has the drawback of not being strictly monotonic with respect to the standard ordering on partitions. Recently, some improvements have been made by taking into account the granularity of partitions. In this paper, we approach the roughness measure in an axiomatic way. After axiomatically defining roughness measure and partition measure, we provide a unified construction of roughness measure, called generalized Pawlak roughness measure, and then explore the properties of this measure. We show that the improved roughness measures in the literature are special instances of our generalized Pawlak roughness measure and introduce three more generalized Pawlak roughness measures as well. The advantage of our axiomatic approach is that some properties of a roughness measure follow immediately as soon as the measure satisfies the relevant axiomatic definition.
histories: to appear in the Fundamenta Informaticae

metadata.title: An axiomatic approach to the roughness measure of rough sets

sections.text: ar Xiv: 091 1.53 95v2 [cs.AI] 25 May 201 0In Pawlak's rough set theory, a set is approximated by a pair of lower and upper approximations. To numerically measure the roughness of an approximation, Pawlak introduced a quantitative measure of roughness using the ratio of the cardinalities of the lower and upper approximation. Although the roughness measure is effective, it has the disadvantage that it is not strictly monotonous with respect to the standard order of partitions. Recently, some improvements have been made, taking into account the granularity of the partitions. In this essay, we approach the measure of roughness in an axiomatic way. After we have axiomatically defined the measure of roughness and partition, we offer a uniform construction of the measure of roughness, which is called the strong Pawlak roughness measure, and then explore the properties of this measure. We show that the improved dimensions of roughness in the literature are directly relevant to the strong instances of our measurement and strong instances of the pair.

sections.heading: 2. Preliminaries
sections.text: This section consists of four subsections. We recall the definition of Pawlak's rough sets in section 2.1. Sections 2.2, 2.3, and 2.4 are dedicated to the roughness measures proposed by Pawlak [23], Xu et al. [35], and Liang et al. [17], respectively. Some necessary properties of these units of measurement are collected for later purposes. [17] Rough setsWe begin by pointing to some basic terms in Pawlak's rough set theory [22, 23]. Let U be a finite and non-empty universal set, and let R U · U have an equivalence relationship to U. Denote by U / R the set of all equivalence classes induced by R. Such equivalence classes are also called elementary propositions; each union (not necessarily empty) of elementary propositions is called a definable set. For each A U one can distinguish A by a pair of upper and upper seams.

sections.heading: 3. An axiomatic definition of roughness measure
sections.text: This section is composed of three subsections. Motivated by the dimensions of roughness in [17, 35], we present an axiomatic definition of roughness and discuss its basic properties in Section 3.1. To construct further dimensions of roughness, we introduce an axiomatic definition of the dimensions of separation in Section 3.2. by integrating the dimensions of roughness in Pawlak's dimension of roughness, we introduce a strong dimension of roughness and examine their properties in Section 3.3.1. roughness measurements for later needs, let us introduce the following idea, which refers to two approximation spaces: Definition 1. sections.heading: 4. Case study of strong Pawlak roughness measures
sections.text: As we have seen in the previous section, if you can show that h is a partition measurement on U, then βh is a strong Pawlak roughness measurement and therefore has the characteristics found in Corollary 3 and Propositions 5, 6, 7 and 8. In this section, we will first consider the roughness measurements βX and βL based on Xu et al. [35] and Liang et al. [17], both within the strong Pawlak roughness measurements, and then provide three new strong roughness measurements. Proposition 9. The roughness measurement βX based on Xu et al. is a strong Pawlak roughness measurement. Proof. By definition, βX roughness measurement is A) = βP roughness measurement, A-Con (G) · (G) · con-U | U-1, which is sufficient to show that it is a strong roughness measurement.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper we have examined roughness measurement in an axiomatic way. Axiomatic definitions of roughness measurement and pitch were provided. On this basis, we have given a uniform construction of roughness measurement, which is called the strong Pawlak roughness measure, by combining the roughness measure in Pawlak's roughness measurement. Some properties of the strong Pawlak roughness measure have also been investigated. Furthermore, we have shown that the existing roughness measurements in [35] and [17] are two special cases of our strong Pawlak roughness measurement that support our axiomatic definitions. The advantage of the axiomatic approach is that it can combine some seemingly different terms. As a result, we can examine the properties of roughness measurement in Definition 2 and weak roughness measurement in Definition 3.

referenceMentions.context: Rough set theory was proposed by Pawlak in the early 1980s [22, 23] as a new mathematical approach for dealing with inexact, uncertain or vague knowledge in information systems.
Since then we have witnessed a systematic, world-wide growth of interest in rough set theory [4, 20, 25, 28, 37, 43, 44, 48, 49, 50, 52].

In order to measure numerically the accuracy of an approximation, Pawlak introduced two quantitative measures of accuracy and roughness in [23]: The accuracy of a subset is defined as the ratio of the cardinalities of the lower and upper approximations of the subset, which is bounded by 0 and 1; the roughness of a subset is calculated by subtracting the accuracy of the subset from 1.

metadata.abstractText: In Pawlak’s rough set theory, a set is approximated by a pair of lower and upper approximations. To measure numerically the roughness of an approximation, Pawlak introduced a quantitative measure of roughness by using the ratio of the cardinalities of the lower and upper approximations. Although the roughness measure is effective, it has the drawback of not being strictly monotonic with respect to the standard ordering on partitions. Recently, some improvements have been made by taking into account the granularity of partitions. In this paper, we approach the roughness measure in an axiomatic way. After axiomatically defining roughness measure and partition measure, we provide a unified construction of roughness measure, called strong Pawlak roughness measure, and then explore the properties of this measure. We show that the improved roughness measures in the literature are special instances of our strong Pawlak roughness measure and introduce three more strong Pawlak roughness measures as well. The advantage of our axiomatic approach is that some properties of a roughness measure follow immediately as soon as the measure satisfies the relevant axiomatic definition.
